campaign.story:
Hey, station managers! We want to talk. Give us a shout here to talk about how The Public Radio could fit into your next fund drive!
It's radio monogamy.
Our interaction with FM radio today is simple - we just turn on and off the power. We rarely change stations, and *never* use those seek and scan buttons.  
We've gotten rid of all the parts of FM that are now obsolete, leaving only what matters. The Public Radio has all you need - just an antenna and a volume knob.
How it works 
Let's get one thing clear: The Public Radio only tunes to one station - your favorite one. When the campaign ends, we'll ask for your station's frequency & call letters, and will tune your Public Radio to that station before it ships.
The Public Radio is secured in place with the Mason jar's screw-on ring. The telescoping antenna screws through the lid, and batteries are accessed by removing the radio and installing them inside.
Tech Details
At the heart of The Public Radio is a Silicon Labs Si4831 FM IC. Its output is passed through a Texas Instruments TPA2005D1 class D amplifier which drives a 4 ohm 1.25” speaker by Dayton Audio. The Public Radio is built on sturdy FR-4 printed circuit board, and houses a couple custom components, including a switched audio taper potentiometer and a seven segment telescoping antenna. The entire assembly is sandwiched together with our stamped stainless steel lid.
We spent a lot of time trying different assembly configurations and hardware specs. If you've got a hankering for details, shoot us a note - we're happy to geek out about it :) You're also welcome to check out our GitHub page, which has open-source versions of our EagleCAD files.
So... Why a Mason jar?
Honestly? It was an accident. At first, we imagined an enclosure with a more contemporary aesthetic. But we needed to evaluate speakers in the meantime, and used a jar and a piece of cardboard as a stand-in. After trying it for an afternoon, we realized that it was just more fun to use something that was *literally* on our shelves.
The standard version of The Public Radio comes with its own 250mL square (ish) Ball jar, but you can swap the hardware out into any wide-mouth jar that you like.
Project History
We've been working hard on the Public Radio for the past eighteen months, iterating our designs and building on feedback we received from our beta launch on Grand St. We've gone through seven PCB revisions to date, and have learned a *ton* about FM reception and circuit design in the process.
For the last three months we have researched, designed and ordered a handful of the custom parts necessary to make a small production run of The Public Radio. This includes the radio's custom potentiometer and antenna, both of which we received this June. We've also spent countless hours poring over our bill of materials, searching for ways to drop costs - and have researched & vetted our supply chain along the way. 
Some of the radio's hardware components (such as the custom lid) require big setup fees, and we need your help to cover them. Support the project by pre-ordering your own Public Radio and help make this a reality!
Who we are
We're Zach Dunham and Spencer Wright, two childhood friends now living in Brooklyn. We ran around together as kids, and then went on to be hardware design, project management, and audio aficionados. After taking MIT's circuits & electronics class, we started hacking together on weekends, and eventually came up with a fun, compelling idea - that we finally had the skills to complete. 
We had *tons* of engineering help from Todd Bailey and Andy Warner. Special thanks to Alexis Arkus-Duntov, Jonathan Bobrow, and Daniel Fishkin for their concepting help, and to Colin Reilly for cinematography. 
We also couldn't have gotten this far without the help of our beta testers - thanks to Robert K, Ross W, Kristen S, Elana O, Harry J, Shawn F, Tracy L, Greg A, Ada P, Jacob C, Robert C, Paula P, Janna L, Cheryl R, Linnea J, Saralyn C, Robert L, and Henry L!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We're confident with our mechanical and electrical design, but some logistical questions remain. Foremost in our minds is building a system that allows us to tune and then track unique radios to each of our backers as they come off of the production line. It'll be a bit tricky, but our fabrication partners are aware of the issue and have a preliminary plan to deal with it.

We're also anticipating some work in the management of vendors and manufacturers of our custom parts. We have parts coming from about a half dozen suppliers, and tracking their progress and dependencies will be a full-time job. But we've managed jobs of greater complexity before, and ultimately this will not be an impossible task. 

Another expense (and logistical hurdle) will be the FCC tests that we're subject to. These will cost a few thousand dollars and will inevitably require a bit of effort and management. But ultimately, our production and testing partners are well-versed in this territory (and the specifications we need to pass are relatively easy), so we feel confident that it won't be a major issue.

We also need to find a clever use for all of the standard Mason jar lids that will come with the Public Radio's jars. We'll probably end up using them to make pickles, and there's always the chance that we ship out jars of those instead of the radios... but we're pretty sure we can keep them straight ;)
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Project Update #9: DFM done & in production!
updates.update_content:
Hey, Publicradioers!
Wow.
So, a lot has happened since our last update. We've been hustling *hard* to get everything into production. The good news: We're on schedule across the board!
Since our last update, we did a bunch more DFM on our circuit design & layout. After a lot of work (and some much needed help from Andy Warner and ), we ended up improving the reception on The Public Radio significantly by switching to a Class-AB audio amplifier (a Texas Instruments TPA6203A1 - more details , if you're interested). After that, we made some final tweaks to the board design (including a cutout on the bottom right that will help us align the boards during assembly), and then officially went into production on the circuit boards.

campaign.story:
Looking for your Coolest? Follow along with all our production news and updates at www.coolest.com/countdown!
A 21st Century Cooler? It's about time!
Regular coolers are boring, break easily and are a hassle to haul around just to carry the ice. The COOLEST cooler is 60 quarts of AWESOME packed with so much fun you'll look for excuses to get outside more often.
Maybe you want to use the built-in ice crushing blender to whip up some margaritas or smoothies on your next boat trip or tailgate?
Maybe you just want to always have music on hand with the waterproof bluetooth speaker or want to recharge your electronics with the built in USB charger?
What else?
REWARDS:
UPDATE:  Color Voting Complete! 
Here are the Final Coolest Color options. When you pledge for a Coolest we'll send you a survey after the campaign to make your color choice.
Scroll on down for more details...                     
      BLENDER
Nothing is more refreshing on a hot day than a cold blended cocktail or smoothie.  The 18 volt ice-crushing beast built into the COOLEST will power through more than 6 gallons of blended goodness on a single charge.
 WATERPROOF WIRELESS SPEAKERS
If life is supposed to be a party, then you better bring the music. You’re gathered around the cooler anyway, but now you can DJ the music right from your phone or Bluetooth-enabled device directly to your COOLEST. Just turn your phone on, match it with the COOLEST speaker, and rock out with your bad self.
                        USB CHARGER
 Since you’ve got that 18 volt battery for the blender, why not get the most out of it? Maybe your camera battery is low or maybe you have an iPhone you just want to use after 3:00 in the afternoon... Re-charge your gear wherever you are with the waterproof USB charger.
                          LED LID LIGHT
The party doesn’t stop just because the sun goes down, and you shouldn’t have to freeze your fingers searching endlessly for your favorite drink.  The COOLEST has unbreakable lights embedded in the lid so you easily find what you’re looking for with the push of a button.
                       GEAR TIE-DOWN
Carrying your gear to and from your destination is a hassle, and your old cooler isn’t doing you any favors.
The COOLEST's locking tie-downs are like having a roof-rack on your cooler so three trips can be done in one. Easily secure your lawn chairs, blankets, towels, toys, fishing tackle, or grill.
                         BEACH TIRES
One of the worst unintended workouts can be had by trying to drag a conventional cooler through a sandy beach.  The COOLEST wheels are twice as wide so they roll easily and don't sink in.
               ESSENTIAL STORAGE
There are certain essentials you need for any outdoor gathering so why not have a built in cubby to store them?  The COOLEST has storage for a half dozen reusable plastic plates, which also double as a cutting board for the ceramic rust-proof pairing knife.  
                SPLIT LID and DIVIDER
The COOLEST has a split lid design so you can get access to ice for the blender without letting too much warm air in.  This also lets you keep your cups in the cup holders so you don't have to put everything on the ground just to grab another cold drink.
The split lid design and removable divider give you some great packing options.  You can keep your cocktail ice separate from your regular ice. Or you could put ice only on one side, pull the drain plug and the other side becomes a totally dry refrigerator, perfect for keeping sandwiches and any other perishable food cool and dry.
                       BOTTLE OPENER
How many hours of your life have been wasted or teeth chipped because someone walked off with the bottle opener.  My grandpa's cooler had a bottle opener and so does the COOLEST.
THE STORY
I’m always looking to maximize my fun when I get together with my family and friends. That’s why I am so passionate about the COOLEST. I invent lots of things, but other than my Jello-shot catapult very few have brought so much fun to my life. ;)
I know firsthand how much fun it is to have a cooler with speakers, and a portable blender for beachside margaritas, because I built myself one of each around ten years ago. Last year I reexamined these well-loved creations and realized just how much room for improvement there was. 
What's next?
I have manufactured and brought other products to market, but for a project of this size and complexity I'll be using a pool of experts in the field to make sure the COOLEST lives up to it’s name.
The professional sourcing company I've partnered with has manufactured other coolers, as well as high tech gear. They have an experienced team in the field to assist with quality control, shipping and and other logistics. 
We want you to have your COOLEST as soon as possible. Here’s our plan to achieve that:
July/August: Make lots of new Kickstarter friends, execute manufacturing agreements/standards
September:Finalize the engineering and prototype iterations and place the tooling orders
October:  Tooling build-out and procurement of raw materials and components
November: Part qualification and pre-production builds, pilot production, quality assurance and product validation
December: Begin manufacturing for the injection molded and blow-molded parts
January/February: Finalize the assembly and shipment process and begin fulfillment
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
No one wants to see a good idea executed poorly, especially one called the COOLEST. We have worked extremely hard to ready this product for Kickstarter and full-scale manufacturing and fulfillment, but here are what I see as the risks:


MANUFACTURING: Creating the tooling to manufacture a product of this size is expensive and requires expert knowledge to get it right. There is typically a 60 day lead time to create the molds for a product of this size and this is where delays could occur. To minimize that possibility we're working with tooling manufacturers partners with a track record for prompt quality.

PRODUCT ADJUSTMENTS: As the COOLEST gets geared up for production, there will likely be some minor adjustments to improve the final product. Pre-production prototypes are made to test and refine the product and allow us to incorporate our adjustments and those suggested by experienced manufacturing partners. These will always be for the benefit of you, the consumer, and we will let you know exactly how and why any are made.

FULFILLMENT: Sometimes things go awry that can’t be planned for: a supplier misses a deadline, a machine breaks down, or a shipment gets lost. Those things could cause a delay. To minimize the possibility of manufacturing setbacks we will enter the manufacturing stage with at least one back-up supplier for each component pre-located and my product commercialization experts will help ensure smooth sailing from our suppliers and factories.

We will be working with manufacturers who have years of experience delivering excellent products in tremendous quantities. There will no doubt be some surprises along the road, but any obstacle will be addressed by combining our internal knowledge with external expertise, and an overall goal of making the best possible product for you, our COOLEST customer.

Any pledge amount brings us one step closer to our goal. Help us make the coolest idea the COOLEST product by clicking the ‘Back This Project’ button at the top of the page, or by helping us spread the word by sharing our page.

We raise a red solo cup of blended goodness in your honor, and say THANK YOU for your help!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
STRETCH GOAL 
Please help us raise our Stretch Goal of $7,500.  The additional funds will put instruments, music supplies, and the magic of music instruction directly into the hands of the young people at Za’atari camp. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts to our first 40 faithful backers who have given this project wings and to our friends in the musical community who have donated materials, strings, reeds, and given us discounts on instruments, books, and teaching materials! Thank you also to the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra for featuring us in their "Stories"!
We now have a place to get instruments in Jordan
With your contribution, your presence, and your concern, you will be part of this special effort to embrace the young people of Syria, who have already suffered so much, in our global circle of caring through the gift and joy of music. Your pledge today will be an investment in a new future of hope and healing for the Children of Syria! 
Children playing at Za'atari Camp
 - - - - - - 
On January 13th, at Carnegie Hall, Music for Life International presented our most recent global humanitarian concert “Shostakovich for the Children of Syria,” for the refugee children of Syria, their families, and communities. At this concert, we made a promise to an audience of more than 1,500 people that we would bring the hope and healing power of music to the Children of Syria in person with a small group gathered from the vast community on stage that evening, 128 musicians from 26 countries and 73 orchestras, ensembles and academies. 
Photo: Jennifer Taylor, used by permission
Now, with your help, we are poised to fulfill that promise. It is one thing to do a concert in beautiful Carnegie Hall for people in need in a distant land. It is another thing to actually show up in person.
This month, we will bring a string quartet of amazing musicians from major orchestras and festivals
Mary Ann Mumm, Violin, MET Orchestra (former)
Deborah Greitzer, Violin, Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra
Craig Mumm, Associate Principal Viola, MET Orchestra
Rosanna Butterfield, Cello Fellow, New World Symphony  "America's Orchestral Academy" and Verbier Festival Orchestra
to Jordan where they will generously share their artistry in a week-long string quartet residency from August 20-27 for young people and their families at Za’atari Refugee Camp, the largest Syrian Refugee Camp in Jordan and the second largest refugee camp in the world. 
We will be performing the music of Shostakovich, Borodin and Haydn. We are also honored to present the music of Syrian composer and Tufts University faculty member, Kareem Roustom, with a special piece for this project. Our residency – a partnership with Questscope, a visionary non-profit organization dedicated to creating social, educational, and entrepreneurial opportunities for marginalized youth, and the world renowned Institute for Global Leadership at Tufts University – will also include music education activities for the youth and children at Za’atari camp. 
Mary Ann Mumm works with youth in Jamaica
THE ROAD TO ZA'ATARI CAMP
The good news is that with the generous support of the Dr. Jean Mayer Global Citizenship Fund from Tufts University's Institute for Global Leadership and our longtime friends George Landegger and Parsons & Whittemore Inc., we have already raised $15,000 of the $20,000 we need for travel, housing, and local expenses. You can get us over the final stretch to the finish line in these next few weeks. 
We will keep you posted with news from Jordan and from Za’atari camp in the days and weeks ahead. Follow our progress and residency on Facebook and Twitter. 
George Mathew with Questscope staff and mentors at Za'atari
PRESS COVERAGE
NEW!
Baltimore Symphony Orchestra "Stories" Music in Za'atari by Ricky O'Bannon (August 17, 2014)
Our previous Children of Syria efforts have been covered by the global media and a major US television network will be accompanying the quartet to cover this residency

The Buffalo News 3 BPO musicians playing tonight in Carnegie Hall charity orchestra

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have had tremendous success with our series of global humanitarian concerts at Carnegie Hall over the last eight years, but this is a very different kind of undertaking with a whole new array of issues, problems and complexities to navigate. These include the logistics of international travel, different nationalities, language, and culture. 

We have already had to reschedule this residency owing to other projects that we and our partners were handling. We are almost ten years old and this sort of recalibration is familiar territory. We are also well into the preparations for our next major global humanitarian effort "THE SCHEHERAZADE INITIATIVE: Celebrating the Resilience of Women and Girls Facing Violence". It is certainly a challenge to have multiple projects moving simultaneously.

A vast refugee camp in the Jordanian desert is a different kind of performing venue from the most prestigious stage in the world, Carnegie Hall, with its amenities, where our previous efforts been located. We are bringing music and healing, we hope, to a community that is only a few dozen miles away from the horrific realities of war in a region that is tense with many different kinds of conflict. The landscape shifts not only daily, but sometime by the hour. Our Artistic Director George Mathew has made two trips to Jordan in preparation for this project, and our staff have ensured that we are prepared for any wrinkles that may arise.

We have handled the bumps as they have appeared and even thrived with the challenges, which have actually helped us to look at ourselves and our work with new eyes and ears. And it is all opening new doors and possibilities as we go about the business of creating transformative social impact through music.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: A Moving Remembrance and Memoir of our Music for The Children of Za'atari
updates.update_content:
"I don’t think that it’s naïve to believe that music can create lasting change in the world." _ Rosanna Butterfield, Cellist
Rosanna Butterfield, Cello Fellow at the New World Symphony - America's Orchestral Academy, wrote this beautiful, moving story about her experience at Za'atari Refugee Camp, in Jordan with our Music For The Children of Za'atari Residency for the Syrian Refugee Children in August.  Click on the link below to read her story.
http://www.nws.edu/SpiritOfMusic.aspx?utm_source=wordfly&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=121714Previews&utm_content=version_A

updates.update_userinfo: You, our generous donors put these instruments into young hands at Za'atari Refugee Camp
updates.update_content:
Dear Backers and Friends,
These are a few of the young and not so young people who encountered the thrill of playing a string instrument for the first time last month at Za'atari, thanks to your support which enabled our new violins to reach them.
One of our partner Questscope's amazing young staffers at Zaatari refugee camp with a new violin donated by Music for Life International for the youth and children there.

updates.update_userinfo: Our Music For Za'atari Residency at Zaatari Refugee Camp - First Report - IT WAS FANTASTIC!
updates.update_content:
Dear Friends and Backers,
Thank you so very much for your extraordinary support and your generous commitment to our MUSIC FOR ZA'ATARI residency last month for the refugee children of Syria at Za'atari Refugee Camp in Jordan. At the moment when the Kickstarter campaign ended, we were already airborne and enroute to Jordan. Imagine how thrilled we were to find out on landing in Amman, Jordan that the campaign had exceeded our original $5000 goal by more than 30%!
Our quartet rehearsing at the Jersey City home of Craig and Mary Ann Mumm for our Music For the Children of Za'atari residency before our departure for Amman

Dear Friends, 
We are so excited to see that the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra ran an article by their staff writer Ricky O'Bannon about our Music For The Children of Za'atari Project on their website yesterday. Please click on the link below to see read it. 
http://www.bsomusic.org/stories/music-in-zaatari.aspx

updates.update_userinfo: $2000 raised in the last 25 hours! Thank you backers and all who are sharing our campaign

We are now less than $1500 to the finish line. Please join us now as the excitement is mounting. You can be part of our parade to and beyond the finish line. 
Thank you and keep sharing and pledging!
George Mathew, Artistic Director

updates.update_userinfo: En route to Za'atari Refugee Camp today

Music For Life International Artistic Director George Mathew travelled to Za'atari refugee camp today to prepare concert logistics at camp for our performances in two weeks time. People here are really excited about our visit and the music we are bringing.

campaign.story:
We look forward to staying in touch throughout this project and afterwards atwww.finexusa.com.
It's About Time Someone Updated Grandma's Old Skillet!
Cast iron is your healthy alternative to pans with mysterious polymer liners - it is the original non-stick cookware. Unfortunately the typical designs are extremely outdated and until now the best skillets have all been antiques.
The US produced the finest cast iron cookware in the world before space age aluminum pans took over. FINEX® is now making heirloom quality cast iron cookware in America for the first time in over half a century!
A Modern Heirloom Quality Skillet in Every Kitchen
FINEX is a completely new approach to the traditional cast iron skillet. Typical skillets have a handle that is pretty much designed to burn you - they are flat and narrow and get just as hot as the pan.
The FINEX skillet has an ergonomic "Speed Cool" polished stainless steel spring handle with a brass cap for easy hanging. The spring design allows the handle to cool much quicker than a standard skillet and it's shaped to fit the natural curve of your hand.
Ergonomic "Speed Cool" Spring Handle
Typical skillets are just too rough and food sticks to rough surfaces.
The FINEX skillet has an ultra-smooth computer machined easy release cooking surface.
CNC Machined Easy Release Cooking Surface
No other skillet on the market has this feature and it's one of the reasons antique skillets are so sought after - they are finally smooth after decades of use. Yours is smooth out of the box.
Another Smooth Move
Typical skillets are awkward to pour from when loaded with food.
The FINEX skillet has our patented octagonal "Multi-Pour" design for 6 pouring directions. This distinctive shape creates natural angles and even makes it easier to slide a spatula under your food when cooking.
Patented Octagonal "Multi-Pour" Design
Just Like Its 12" Big Brother
Our 8" FINEX skillet is lighter but no lightweight in the kitchen. It has all of the benefits of our 12" skillet in a more compact size. The outer diameter of this 8" skillet is 8.75" from rim to rim.
Dialing in the CAD Model Before 3D Printing
This is your perfect everyday skillet and the design will make you want to give one to all your friends and family members to share the joy of cast iron cooking.
Carefully Assembling the 3D Printed Prototype
Our 1st skillet, the ultra-smooth 12" FINEX shown below with the 8" 3D printed prototype for comparison, was a runaway success on Kickstarter last winter with over 1,500 backers.
2/3 as Big with 100% of the Performance
Thousands of FINEX No.12s are now in use around the world doing what cast iron does best - perfectly searing, grilling and sautéing your families favorite foods.
The Iconic FINEX No. 12 (Included for $240 Pledge!)
But Where Can I Place My Hot New FINEX Skillet?
Our team has your back, so we created this beautiful, laser-cut American cherry wood trivet to showcase the exceptionally clean and timeless FINEX logo created by iconic graphic designer Aaron Draplin.
Cherry Wood Trivet Dimensions: 8" wide x 8" tall x .5" thick.
Functional art for your wall or table - this cherry wood finished trivet has precision laser cut detail, cushioned feet and is available in limited numbers for a $35 pledge.
The 12" FINEX Cast Iron Lid is Coming Soon!
Testing the 12" Cast Iron Lid Prototype
Are You Cast Iron Crazy?
No doubt about it! I'm passionate about cast iron because every pan tells a story. Each skillet holds an entire history of meals and memories. 20 years, 30 years, even just one year, all imbued with flavors, experiments, laughter and conversations. Your history is built one meal at a time and it deserves to be made in a premium American skillet.
By pledging towards the innovative 8" FINEX skillet you'll personally bring heirloom quality cast iron cookware back to America. Absolutely none of this would be possible without your support and I thank you for that.
Mike Writing Personal Thank You Notes to Backers
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
For two decades, I have overseen complex manufacturing and design projects in aerospace, consumer goods and optics. I also ran a successful Kickstarter project last winter, so I’m well aware of the challenges and pitfalls involved in completing another one.

At the launch of this project, FINEX has its own facility with a full time team, our CAD modeling is done, multiple 3D printed prototypes have been tested, the casting pattern is ready to be machined and the spring house and the foundry have been selected.

Our entire supply chain is within a day's drive of our facility in Portland, Oregon and largely within my existing manufacturing relationships. I haven't just grabbed the lowest quote and hoped they might deliver - I know many of them, have worked with many of them and have visited and grilled the others to verify their credentials.

I've run the numbers in the business plan, crunched the schedule and feel confident that we can meet our estimated delivery to your doorstep.

SUMMARY: All that is left to get this skillet cooking is for you to tell us you agree with our vision by pledging to support the project.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear FINEX Friends,
We are there! We have fulfilled all of your pledges (see photo for the last group of sets being shipped). Thank you for your very generous support with every step and understanding through every challenge. The support each and every one of you have shown has been a privilege that has made this vision of modern American heirloom possible and thriving. 
We can’t thank you enough for your patience and encouragement. We are later on deliveries than we had hoped but are excited to have the new 8" skillet now fully available on our site and soon be out of back order for all of our products. If you haven’t received received a shipping confirmation, please send an email to cookwithus@finexusa.com with your shipping information since we still have several names without a shipping address or contact info.

Dear FINEX friends,
It's that time of year and I speak for the entire FINEX team when I say that we wish you a truly wonderful Holidays and New Year!
This is a good time to also provide a quick update on our status and progress.  We've been working hard to improve our processes at every level and we are excited to have succeeded on several fronts.  The new milling operation has resulted in our desired truly smooth cooking surface.  The new machined brass cap on the handle, versus our original casting approach, has enabled a very consistent look for the full handle.  These changes and other process improvements have all been incorporated into the skillets already shipped and continue in the future.

project_data.project_name: FINEX 8” Cast Iron Skillet: A 21st Century Heirloom

campaign.story:
As seen on:
Our new wind meter
Wind is an important factor for a wide range of activities, but the greatest places in the great outdoors are far away from any weather station. In order to give you precise and sharable wind readings on the spot, we created the first Vaavud wind meter and launched it here on Kickstarter. People loved it!
Now we are back to launch the world's first handheld wind meter that actually measures wind direction, as well as of course wind speed.
This is made possible by our unique asymmetrical rotor design (for further details scroll down to the technical stuff).
We have gone through countless iterations on the rotor design and we have obsessed about every little line and detail, to make sure that both performance and looks are second to none.
The Vaavud app
The new device will work with the popular Vaavud app, which features the world's first real-time graph on a handheld wind meter; a global live map; your personal measurement history and much more to come.
              Device compatibility
Currently we have confirmed the new device to work with the following phones and tablets, and the list keeps growing!

*iPods do not have a compass, so on those the app will show wind speed, but not wind direction
Timeline
We are working towards a shipping date in November 2014, and so far all is set to achieve that target
Rewards
Stretch goals
Colour choice: The third colour will be the one that gets the most votes from all backers, once the campaign is over. More info on this will follow when we get there
Mount + data export: The mount will be printable on most common 3D printers, and will be designed to work with a standard jack-stick extender cable. The design files will be made available, so you can do all the modifications you want to. The data export feature will upload a time series for each measurement as a CSV file to a dropbox folder of your choice
Special carry case: This will be a neoprene hard case similar to the ones known from Oakley sunglasses etc. but tailor made to the Vaavud wind meter. We are quite happy with the current neoprene bags, but this will be something special; a snug fitting, robust, exclusive case made just for your Vaavud V2.0
Welcome on board!
Our Kickstarter legacy
Comments from backers and press about our first Kickstarter campaign
The technical stuff
We are using an optical sensor that measures 40.000 times per second, so we can detect even the slightest variation in rotation speed. By making the rotor of the wind meter slightly asymmetrical we get it to accelerate a bit when the largest part is hit by the wind. We can then compare the point with the highest speed to the compass direction and derive the wind direction. At the same time, data from the highly accurate sensor can be used to derive the average rotation speed and thereby the wind speed.
The graph below shows the change in velocity during one full rotation for one of our prototypes. For this one the difference in speed is a bit more than 3%, and the maximum speed is reached at about 45 degrees from start.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Any hardware project faces risks - there is no denying that. But we are at a point, where we have eliminated practically all technical risks, so now it is a matter of getting the final design details in place, source the components, and get production started.

Things can of course get delayed in the production process, because rework is needed after seeing the initial production samples, or because a component from a sub-supplier is delayed or turns out not to be in the right quality etc. etc. etc.

However, we learned a lot from launching our first product here on Kickstarter. It went pretty smooth, but we can also see lots of big and small things that we can improve. Furthermore we have teamed up with a great design & engineering company here in Denmark, to help us with finding and managing suppliers - something they have a lot of experience with. So we are doing everything we can, to identify any bumps on the road well in advance, and on managing our way around the ones that will inevitably appear.

Furthermore we have our entire logistics set-up in place. This is one of the biggest headaches for a hardware project, with backers from all around the globe. But we have this up and running, so even if production gets delayed, we should be able to absorb all or most of it, because our shipping will run smoothly.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: The Vaavud ULTRASONIC wind meter is here
updates.update_content:
Hey Backers,
We hope you are all well! 
We wanted to share a bit of exciting news with you: We are launching the Vaavud ULTRASONIC - a solar-powered, Bluetooth connected, ultrasonic wind meter.  
It has no wires, is super compact, and weighs only 130 grams, so you can mount it practically anywhere! The 4 ultrasonic transducers register wind flow with very high accuracy and sensibility, and since the device has no moving parts it is extremely durable.

Hi backers,
First of all, thank you so much again guys to have supported us through this amazing journey. We have been so stoked to received so many positive comments and see those red spots spread all over the world on the map :-) Here are some of our favourite comments:
"Received my Vaavud today and I have only one thing to say ......UNBELIEVABLE !!!!!!” Peter 
"Received mine a while back and immediately used it as part of my aerial photography and video business. Brilliant device and love how it just works. Well done.” Philippe

Hi' All,
We have just walked through the software issues we have experienced so far, and wanted to share the status. We are sorry that you have experienced a number of malfunctions - it has not been the amazing first time experience that we wanted to provide - but the good news is that we have our hands around all of the issues, and that they will be resolved soon.
Android users

Hi Guys,
Just a quick comment now - more to follow later.
Every single device is tested at the end of the assembly line. Each device is plugged into an iPhone that is mounted in front of a fan and runs a test app, and only if every step of the test produces an "OK", the device is packed and shipped. I.e. the electronics are definitely functioning. So what you are experiencing is a software issues, and here is why:

Hi' all,
If you check the map in the Vaavud app, you can see that the Sleipnir wind meters have started to arrive around the world. So far we have spotted Sleipnir readings in Portland, Denver and San Antonio in the US, and in Cape Town, Mahlberg, London, Paris and Copenhagen and a few other places. You can recognize them on the small red arrow, which indicates the wind direction.

Hi’ backers,
Thanks a lot for your patience, but we are happy to announce that the wait is over!!!
The last couple of months have been equal parts frustration and excitement for us, because every time we were sure that the finish line would appear in the distance juuust as we turned that next corner, there proved to be yet another corner and another one and…

Hi' all,
We finally got around to send out the backer survey, so you should all receive it very shortly - if you have not received it already.
But much more importantly: We have finally cleared the last roadblock on the road to the first production run!!

updates.update_userinfo: One more update update regarding the backer survey
updates.update_content:
Hi' all,
We discovered a few errors with "regular" backers who received the survey that was specifically made for the premium backers (because these need to choose between to alternative rewards). This survey was sent to 75 people in total.
If you have received the premium survey in error, and already filled it in then that's no problem. We will just ignore the question where you have chosen one of the two premium rewards - but we will of course still have your shipping details etc.
